creator: cg.risd5

content:
If you have two AOL smtp servers that are the same except for the User Name (email address), then make sure each account is set to use the correct smtp. For this purpose, it helps to give each smtp a distinct Description.

Select account 1 in the left pane of Account Settings and check that Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the right pane points to smtp 1, and that account 2 points to smtp 2. You might have to remove the entries from Saved Passwords in Settings, restart TB, and enter the passwords in the OAuth window for each account.

content:
Is this a profile or just an mbox? The import feature you are using is for a profile. If it is only an mbox, my suggestion is to:

  1. unzip to a local folder
  2. install the addon, imporexporttools NG,
  3. highlight Local Folders
  4. rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox and then locate and select the unzipped file.

content:
Let's clarify what you are trying to import.

You asked about "a zip file of an MBOX file for entire email account". That does not make sense. mbox files are not usually zipped, and they do not hold data for an entire e-mail account. Profiles get zipped and they do hold data for an entire e-mail account. Combined with this statement ...

uncommon7441 said
This crazy. I select the file to import and it starts importing an existing email backup from years ago unrelated to the file I selected. I have never interacted with such a frustrating extension.

..., the evidence suggests that you have a backed-up profile that you are treating as an mbox file.

Then you asked about importing a pst file, which is a third thing that you could import, but that would require a third, different approach.

What exactly are you trying to accomplish?
creator: mozilla98

content: I agree, we need to know from exactly where this mbox came from, what application created it, and what OS.
creator: wsmwk

content: Check the settings for each account: incoming IMAP server mail.twc.com, 993, SSL/TLS, normal password, email address; outgoing SMTP server mail.twc.com, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, email address. There should be separate smtp servers for each account, with the same settings except the User Name (email address).

creator: tech29

content:
Ok, if I may share a personal observation: most users want to display emails in their preferred font, not in yours. Receiving messages in Consolas/large may not be well-received by some, and others may have their email client set to show their font only. Ok, end of homily. :)

For consistency, I suggest setting the font as desired and then leave it alone. I verified this by changing my default to consolas/large and I had consistency in sent folder and in inbox. HTML isn't like a wordprocessor; it you do overrides throughout the message, you can lose the settings desired. Good luck.

Sidenote: if you real intent is for your viewing, thunderbird can be set so that you see consolas/large on messages and others see in their preferred font. That's a possibility.

I recommend doing that from your online account. THunderbird is not designed for that

Definitely a good choice, if the vendor of the online account supplies that capability.

content:
È attiva l'autenticazione a 2 fattori? Inoltre, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
Hi George,

The first thing that I would do is see what options there are in webmail at your e-mail service provider to increase the sensitivity to spam/junk so that the filtering happens at the server before messages even get to Thunderbird.

Then, in Thunderbird, you can use message filters under the "Tools" menu to create rules that will automatically send messages from certain domains to trash.

But if you have to do that for many domains, which you will, you're going to spend more time editing the message filters than you want to. You'll probably want to turn on junk filters in Thunderbird and do some training after all.
creator: mozilla98

content:
If you reacted to the appeal in Thunderbird which suggested you change to 139, then you saw https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release/ which also has the instructions for going back to 128.

Before you do that, you might want to try some easy steps, and if they help then some recommendations can be made to help you.

  • Start Windows in safe mode with networking enabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still In Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does problem change?
creator: wsmwk
